head.hi:
A Letter from Humboldt, Praying Re-
lease From the Letter Writers.

div.p:
—The
venerable Humboldt thus appeals for mercy
to a class which was never yet known to
spare either sex or age:

Suffering beneath the pressure of a still
increasing correspondence, amounting to
between sixteen hundred and two thousand
communications per annum, and embrac-
ing letters, printed pamphlets on matters
which I am wholly unacquainted, manu-
scripts concerning which my opinion is de-
sired, projects for emigration and coloniz-
ing, the sending of models, machines and
natural curiosities, request of contributions
to collections of autographs, efforts to take
charge of my domestic concerns, to cheer
and enliven me, &c., &c., I must again
publicly urge all persons having my wel-
fare at heart to exert their influence in my
behalf, that individuals on both continents
may no longer busy themselves with my
person and make of my house an intelli-
gence office; and that I be allowed, in the
declining state of my physical and mental
powers, to enjoy some rest and leisure to
attend to my duties. May this cry for re-
lief, which I utter with much reluctance
and after reflection, not meet an unfriend-
ly interpretation!
